message:
SYSTEM: 03_RDF%28S%29.pdf: Página 17
RDF Containers
•
There is often the need to describe groups of things
–
A book was created by several authors
–
A lesson is taught by several persons
–
etc
etc.
•
RDF provides a container vocabulary
–
rdf:Bag Æ A group of resources or literals, possibly including duplicate members, 
where the order of members is not significant.
–
rdf:Seq Æ A group of resources or literals, possibly including duplicate members, 
where the order of members is significant.
–
rdf:Alt Æ A group of resources or literals that are alternatives (typically for a 
single value of a property).
© O. Corcho, R.García-Castro, O. Muñoz-García
34
RDF and RDF Schema
oeg:Oscar
“ocorcho@fi.upm.es”
“oscar.corcho@upm.es”
rdf:_1
person:hasEmailAddress
rdf:_2
rdf:Seq
rdf:type
RDF Reification
•
RDF statements about other RDF statements
–
“Raúl believes that Oscar’s birthdate is on Feb 2nd, 1976 and that his e-mail 
address is ocorcho@fi.upm.es”
oeg:Raúl
oeg:Oscar
“ocorcho@fi.upm.es”
02/02/1976
person:hasEmailAddress
modal:believes
person:hasBirthDate
© O. Corcho, R.García-Castro, O. Muñoz-García
35
RDF and RDF Schema
•
RDF Reification
–
Allows expressing beliefs (and other modalities)
–
Allows expressing trust models, digital signatures,etc.
–
Allows expressing metadata about metadata
